theoryTitle: Chopper's Low Bounty: Secret Marine Admirer
theoryText: Some fans theorize that Chopper has a secret admirer within the Marines, possibly Captain Jiriroto as suggested in One Piece: Fan Letter, who intentionally keeps his bounty low to protect him. This would explain why despite his significant contributions and powerful Monster Point form, he's still treated as a pet.
author: Various One Piece fans
evidencePoints: Chopper's bounty remains absurdly low despite major battles
The Marines never seem to witness him in combat
Similar pattern with Bepo who also has a very low bounty
counterArguments: Could simply be a running gag by Oda
Marines genuinely mistake him for a pet based on appearance
No concrete evidence of a Marine admirer exists in the main story

theoryText: A theory suggests that the World Government purposely keeps bounties low for certain mink-like characters (Chopper, Bepo) to hide information about the Mink race and their connection to Zunesha and potentially Joy Boy. This would be propaganda to prevent attention on this important race.
author: Various theorists
evidencePoints: Bepo, a powerful mink and second-in-command, also has an absurdly low bounty of 1,500 berries
The Minks have important connections to the Void Century
World Government has history of hiding information
counterArguments: Chopper is a reindeer, not a mink
The theory requires a massive conspiracy for what appears to be a gag
Other minks like Pedro and the Musketeers have normal bounties

theoryText: The mysterious giant shadows in the Florian Triangle are theorized to be umibōzu, enormous traditional Japanese sea monsters said to drown sailors. The creatures greatly resemble traditional depictions of these yokai, being enormous with red eyes and able to blend into fog. They would explain the hundreds of ships that go missing in the Florian Triangle every year.
author: Various One Piece theorists
evidencePoints: The creatures' appearance matches traditional umibōzu descriptions
Ships disappear in the Florian Triangle even before Moria arrived
Over 100 ships disappear yearly, more than Moria could account for
Oda frequently incorporates Japanese folklore into One Piece
counterArguments: Could be connected to other mysteries in the series

theoryTitle: Florian Triangle Entities: Imu's Remote Ability
theoryText: A theory proposes that Imu, the secret ruler of the World Government, created or controls the mysterious entities in the Florian Triangle using some remote ability. Since Imu is unhappy about pirates exploring the sea in search of Poneglyphs, attacking pirate ships in dangerous areas like the Florian Triangle would serve their interests in maintaining control and preventing discovery of the Void Century's secrets.
author: Various theorists
evidencePoints: The World Government benefits from pirates disappearing
The entities target ships heading to important locations
Would explain why the phenomenon predates Moria
counterArguments: No direct evidence connecting Imu to the Florian Triangle
Imu's powers haven't been fully revealed
Simpler explanations may exist (natural sea monsters)
The theory relies on unconfirmed assumptions about Imu's abilities

theoryTitle: Sanji's Drawing Poster: Duval Connection Setup
theoryText: Fans theorized after Episode 320 that Sanji's poorly drawn wanted poster would lead to future complications. This theory was proven correct when Duval appeared, a man whose face exactly matched Sanji's drawn poster, leading him to be hunted in Sanji's place and creating his grudge against Sanji.
author: One Piece fans (2007-2008)
evidencePoints: The unusual nature of the drawn poster seemed intentionally setup for future plot
Oda typically doesn't include random details without payoff
Was confirmed when Duval appeared in the Sabaody Archipelago arc
counterArguments: This theory was proven correct, no longer speculation
